content: First part of Calculus I covering limits, derivatives, and applications of derivatives. Prepares students for MATH 122B.
Second part of Calculus I covering integration and applications of integrals. Completes Calculus I sequence.
Single-semester Calculus I covering limits, derivatives, integration, and applications. Accelerated alternative to MATH 122A/B sequence.
Continuation of Calculus I covering techniques of integration, applications of integration, sequences, series, and parametric equations.

metadata.prerequisites: MATH 122B or MATH 125 with C or higher

content: Mathematical foundations for computer science including logic, sets, relations, functions, recursion, graph theory, and combinatorics. Essential for algorithm analysis and software engineering.

General chemistry course covering atomic structure, chemical bonding, stoichiometry, and chemical reactions. Includes laboratory component. Satisfies General Education: Exploring Perspectives (Natural Scientist) requirement.
Honors general chemistry covering fundamental chemical principles with greater depth than CHEM 151.
Laboratory component for CHEM 161 providing hands-on experience with chemical experiments and techniques.
Continuation of CHEM 151 covering thermodynamics, kinetics, equilibrium, and electrochemistry. Includes laboratory component.
Continuation of CHEM 161 with honors-level coverage of advanced chemistry topics.
Laboratory component for CHEM 162.
Introduction to materials science and solid-state chemistry covering crystal structures, bonding in solids, and material properties.
Introduction to biological principles including cell structure, genetics, evolution, and ecology.

Calculus-based physics covering kinematics, dynamics, energy, momentum, rotation, and oscillations. Includes laboratory component. Satisfies General Education: Exploring Perspectives (Natural Scientist) requirement.

metadata.prerequisites: MATH 122B, 125 or Appropriate Math Placement Level

content: Honors version of PHYS 141 with more rigorous treatment of mechanics topics.

metadata.prerequisites: High math placement or permission of instructor

content: Calculus-based physics covering electrostatics, electric circuits, magnetism, and electromagnetic induction. Includes laboratory component.

metadata.prerequisites: PHYS 141 or 140 or 161H; MATH 129 or Appropriate Math Placement

content: Honors version of PHYS 241 with deeper coverage of electromagnetic theory.
Introduction to academic writing focusing on critical reading, analysis, and research-based argumentation.
Alternative first-year composition course with different thematic focus.
Honors version of first-year composition with more rigorous reading and writing requirements.
Continuation of first-year composition with emphasis on research writing and rhetorical analysis.
Alternative second-semester composition course.
First part of introduction to engineering course covering engineering disciplines, design process, and professional skills.

metadata.prerequisites: Pre- or Co-requisite of MATH 112 or higher; First-Year Status; College of Engineering Major; must not have taken ENGR 102

content: Second part of introduction to engineering course with hands-on projects and teamwork.
Single-semester introduction to engineering covering multiple disciplines, design process, and engineering fundamentals.

metadata.prerequisites: Pre- or Co-requisite of MATH 112 or higher; First-Year Status; College of Engineering Major

content: Introduction to University of Arizona general education requirements and academic success strategies.

metadata.course_title: Introduction to the General Education Experience

content: Culminating general education experience where students reflect on and synthesize their learning across general education courses.

This course introduces students to the different software development lifecycle (SDLC) phases used in developing, delivering, and maintaining software products. Students will also acquire basic software development skills and understand common terminology used in the software engineering profession. Students will also learn and practice using traditional coding standards/guidelines. Python software development libraries and debugging tools will be explored and used in projects to familiarize students with basic tasks involved in modifying, building, and testing software. The course will also lay the foundation for achieving academic and career success in Software Engineering.

metadata.grading_basis: GRD - Regular Grades A, B, C, D, E

content: This course is a colloquium designed to help students explore different career opportunities for Software Engineering professionals. Students will interact and learn from professional software engineers while exploring various roles that software engineers play in solving real engineering problems. The course helps students determine focus areas within the SFWE degree program related to specific application areas of interest. Additionally, students will prepare a professional technically focused resume highlighting their skills and experience. Students will explore strategies on how to secure an internship position in diverse industries prior to completing their BS degrees.

metadata.grading_basis: GRD - Regular Grades A, B, C, D, E

content: This course will teach students how to derive and develop software requirements that are measurable, testable and lead to a compliant software design and implementation. Using industry best practices and tools, students will learn how to elicit, analyze, specify, and validate functional and non-functional software requirements. Students will develop software requirements models and specifications that capture the customer/user's needs. They will also develop test plans and test procedures used in a formal software acceptance test to validate that the developed product meets its requirements as specified. In doing so, students will learn and use basic Java language constructs to implement specified requirements. Additionally, students will also learn how to establish and maintain a software requirement configuration baseline, and the processes used to incorporate subsequent changes, updates, and enhancements to the software requirements over time.

metadata.grading_basis: GRD - Regular Grades A, B, C, D, E

content: This course teaches students how to deal with data persistence in software systems. Students learn to model data and use mathematical models to normalize them to avoid redundancy. Backed by theory, they will learn to design database schemes to persist and retrieve application data in an optimal way and consider its representation in the object-oriented system design. This course will walk through the structured query languages and object-oriented design languages used by modern frameworks like Java Persistence API. Students will gain the industry practice of object-relational mapping to connect the benefits of object-oriented design and relational data models.

metadata.grading_basis: GRD - Regular Grades A, B, C, D, E

content: Software plays a vital role in modern life, managing essential services, like the financial systems, social networks, the Internet, and Cyber-Physical Systems, to name a few. Modern software must be bug-free, secure, and function reliably while controlling our critical systems. Software Assurance is the level of confidence in software being free of intentional or accidental vulnerabilities (including flaws, faults, and bugs) inserted at any time during its lifecycle.

metadata.grading_basis: GRD - Regular Grades A, B, C, D, E

content: This course will allow software engineering students to explore key principles of a DevSecOps approach to software development. Development (Dev) and operations (Ops) is the union of people, process, and technology to continually automate and develop higher quality/more reliable software products faster. Security (Sec) is integrated into a typical DevOps pipeline to address potential security issues in code as soon as possible in the software development lifecycle.

metadata.recommended: SFWE 401 Recommended prior to taking this course
metadata.grading_basis: GRD - Regular Grades A, B, C, D, E

content: This course will teach software engineering students how to plan, track and communicate the status of large-scale software projects to a diverse group of stakeholders. Using modern traditional and Agile software development methodologies and tools, and emulating a realistic software development project, students will be immersed in the activities used by industry to develop, manage, and monitor the development of a software product throughout the semester. Students will learn why planning a software project is important, what constitutes a good plan, how to adapt to the unexpected and unknowns that are likely to occur throughout the project development, and how to track and share the status of the project with their team members, other teams, and the customers/business managers. They will also learn how to monitor and track cost expenditures and compare against allocated budgets. Along the way, students will learn the importance of identifying risks and how to develop mitigation plans to address those risks, learn the role that software quality plays in project management, and have the opportunity to develop/hone their leadership and team collaboration skills while being part of an Agile team.

metadata.grading_basis: GRD - Regular Grades A, B, C, D, E

content: While software architecture is the blueprint of the system, the design deals with the modularization of system parts to properly separate concerns to objects and components while aiming to accomplish various quality attributes. This course gives students a critical overview of software architecture and elaborates on enterprise architecture design. It introduces basics to enterprise frameworks to design specific concepts and deal with concerns or particular system layers. Students will manage basic enterprise technology to develop middleware for web-based systems with desired functionality according to common standards and understand enterprise concepts.

metadata.grading_basis: GRD - Regular Grades A, B, C, D, E

content: This course will provide students with the foundational skills and knowledge used by software engineers in diverse industries. Students will understand what software engineering is and why it is more than 'just writing code'. The course introduces students to the different software development lifecycle (SDLC) phases used in developing, delivering, and maintaining software products for a wide variety of applications. Common software process models will be introduced, along with developing an understanding of the importance of defining software requirements, developing software architectures and designs, and the various forms of testing that go into delivering reliable and resilient software systems.

metadata.notes: This course is not required for students majoring in Software Engineering as an undergrad or if the student graduated with a degree in Software Engineering at the University of Arizona
metadata.grading_basis: GRD - Regular Grades A, B, C, D, E

content: Underlying technologies and concepts that create current cloud computing infrastructure. Hands-on experience in designing and implementing modern cloud applications. Cloud has become de facto computing infrastructure in many business and research organizations.

metadata.prerequisites: Advanced Standing: Engineering and (ECE 369A or CSC 252)

content: Design and implementation of distributed systems based on cloud-native approach with up-to-date software architecture and relevant development frameworks. Topics include inter-module communication, asynchronous processing, security, concurrency, parallelism, and contemporary enterprise technology.

metadata.prerequisites: Advanced Standing and successful completion of SFWE 405/505 or CSE/CS equivalents

content: Industrial Control Systems (ICS) and cyber-physical systems in context of Fourth Industrial Revolution (4IR). Connected systems amalgamating artificial intelligence, advanced robotics, smart sensors, and communication networks for industrial automation.

Introduction to basic principles of programming and C programming language. Fundamental software design principles and commonly used techniques to solve computational problems. Covers program flow control, memory management, and elementary data structures.

metadata.prerequisites: MATH 112, 120R, 122B or 125 or placement at the level of MATH 120R

content: Continuation of programming fundamentals building on ECE 101. Advanced programming concepts and problem-solving techniques.

Introduction to digital logic design including Boolean algebra, combinational and sequential logic circuits, and digital system design. Fundamental concepts for computer architecture and digital systems.

metadata.prerequisites: ECE 101; Concurrent enrollment or completion of MATH 129

content: Exploration of ethical issues in engineering practice, professional responsibility, and contemporary challenges facing engineers in society.
Computer architecture and organization including instruction set architecture, processor design, memory hierarchy, and I/O systems. Fundamental understanding of how computers work.
Modeling and design of complex systems using Unified Modeling Language (UML). Focus on object-oriented analysis and design principles.
Probability theory and statistical methods applied to engineering problems. Covers probability distributions, hypothesis testing, and statistical inference.

metadata.course_title: Introduction to Engineering Probability and Statistics

content: Mathematical foundations for computer science including logic, sets, relations, functions, recursion, graph theory, and combinatorics. Essential for algorithm analysis and software engineering.
Introduction to discrete mathematics and fundamental algorithms. Covers logic, proof techniques, combinatorics, and basic algorithm design and analysis.
First semester of two-semester capstone design experience. Students work in interdisciplinary teams on real-world engineering projects, applying knowledge from across their curriculum.
Second semester of two-semester capstone design experience. Students complete their capstone projects, present results, and demonstrate engineering professionalism.

Graduate-level course on secure software coding standards and defensive programming techniques. Ensures software functions correctly, free from errors and bugs. Promotes software integrity, security, quality, and reliability. Concurrent with SFWE 401.

Graduate-level course on DevSecOps workflow approach with industry tools. Using DevSecOps workflows and CI/CD approaches, students assess software quality and reliability improvements. Concurrent with SFWE 402.

metadata.prerequisites: ECE 275 recommended prior to enrollment or equivalent

content: Graduate-level course on planning and tracking progress of Agile software development projects using metrics. Monitor team performance, predict cost and schedule execution, develop risk mitigation plans, and measure software quality and maturity.

Graduate-level course teaching students to derive and develop measurable, testable software requirements that lead to compliant software design and implementation. Industry best practices for eliciting, analyzing, specifying, and validating functional and non-functional requirements.

Graduate-level exploration of processes, methods, and tools for modeling and designing software systems. Industry best practices, design patterns, and modeling tools for software architecture and design.

Unique aspects and considerations for developing large-scale software products in distributed computing environments. Distributed processing and data storage across multiple devices or systems rather than single central device.

Graduate-level study of software development lifecycle (SDLC) phases. Common software process models, requirements definition, architecture and design development, and testing for reliable and resilient software systems. Concurrent with SFWE 407.

metadata.prerequisites: Programming experience in any language strongly recommended

content: Graduate-level course on underlying technologies and concepts creating current cloud computing infrastructure. Hands-on experience designing and implementing modern cloud applications. Concurrent with SFWE 409.

Graduate-level course on design and implementation of distributed systems based on cloud-native approach. Up-to-date software architecture and development frameworks. Topics include inter-module communication, asynchronous processing, security, concurrency, parallelism. Concurrent with SFWE 410.

metadata.prerequisites: Graduate standing and completion of SFWE 505 or equivalent

content: Graduate-level course on Industrial Control Systems (ICS) and cyber-physical systems in Fourth Industrial Revolution context. Connected systems with AI, robotics, smart sensors, and communication networks for industrial automation. Concurrent with SFWE 411.

Basic introduction to principles, methods, and techniques of engineering research. Fundamentals of scientific method and inquiry, ethical considerations in research, quantitative and qualitative data collection methods, and strengths/weaknesses of various data collection approaches.
Directed doctoral research in software engineering. Students conduct original research under supervision of faculty advisor toward completion of dissertation.
Final dissertation writing and defense preparation for PhD candidates in Software Engineering.
Research for the doctoral dissertation (whether library research, laboratory or field observation or research, artistic creation, or dissertation writing).

metadata.grading_basis: SPF - Alternative Grading S, P, F

content: Research for the master's thesis (whether library research, laboratory or field observation or research, artistic creation, or thesis writing). Maximum total credit permitted varies with the major department.

metadata.grading_basis: SPF - Alternative Grading S, P, F

content: Individual research by graduate students.

metadata.grading_basis: SPF - Alternative Grading S, P, F

content: This course is designed to provide a flexible topics course across several domains in the field of Software Engineering. Students will develop and exchange scholarly information in a small group setting.

metadata.grading_basis: SPF - Alternative Grading S, P, F

content: Directed Research courses are intended to cover advanced material outside of or beyond the scope of current course offerings. In such courses, the student will work on a research project under the direct supervision of a Software Engineering faculty member. The research topic should be relevant to MS degree competencies and contribute to the development of the student's knowledge and skill sets in the field of Software Engineering. The student should propose a research plan including the expected outcome and the faculty advisor should approve it before registration. The research plan should include a problem statement, proposed research methods, expected outcome, a schedule of research activities and meeting schedule between the student and the faculty advisor, and the assessment of the student's performance. The amount of the work should be appropriate for the requested credits. The primary faculty advisor must be an SFWE/SIE faculty member, but faculty members from other units may participate in advising the student.

metadata.prerequisites: Graduate standing and faculty advisor approval
metadata.grading_basis: GRD - Regular Grades A, B, C, D, E

content: This course provides a basic introduction to the principles, methods, and techniques of engineering research. Topics include the fundamentals of the scientific method and scientific inquiry, ethical considerations in research, basic methods of quantitative and qualitative data collection, and strengths and weaknesses of various data collection methods. The course is designed to make you a more informed consumer of scientific research through discussion, analysis, and hands-on practice.

metadata.grading_basis: GRD - Regular Grades A, B, C, D, E

content: The increased connectivity due to the rise of the Internet and the growth of smart connected devices (Internet of Things) has brought rapid changes in cyber physical systems operational in many areas including manufacturing, healthcare, transportation, power system, home automation, etc. These changes, dubbed as the Fourth Industrial Revolution (4IR), amalgamate artificial intelligence, advanced robotics, smart sensors, and communication networks, blurring lines between the physical, digital, and biological worlds to automate industrial processes. At the forefront of this revolution are connected Industrial Control Systems (ICS), a group of control systems and associated instrumentation, which include the devices, systems, networks, and controls used to operate and/or automate industrial processes. As ICS and automation become more critical components of our digital world, it will be critical for engineers to know to design, develop, control, and manage these ICS. Moreover, the engineers will not just design and develop optimized ICS; they will also have to ensure their security from cyberattacks.

metadata.grading_basis: GRD - Regular Grades A, B, C, D, E

content: Design and implementation of distributed systems based on a cloud-native approach with up-to-date software architecture and relevant development frameworks. Topics include inter-module communication, asynchronous processing, security, concurrency, parallelism, and an overview of contemporary enterprise technology and challenges.

metadata.recommended: Knowledge of Spring framework and RestAPI
metadata.grading_basis: GRD - Regular Grades A, B, C, D, E

content: Cloud has become a de facto computing infrastructure in many business and research organizations to deliver various user-facing, business, and scientific applications to end users. In this course, you will learn the underlying technologies and concepts that create the current cloud computing infrastructure, and obtain hands-on experience in designing and implementing modern cloud applications.

metadata.recommended: Data structures, operating systems, distributed systems, and computer networks are not required, but prior knowledge of those courses is recommended
metadata.grading_basis: GRD - Regular Grades A, B, C, D, E

content: This course will provide students with the foundational skills and knowledge used by software engineers in diverse industries. Students will understand what software engineering is and why it is more than 'just writing code'. The course introduces students to the different software development lifecycle (SDLC) phases used in developing, delivering, and maintaining software products for a wide variety of applications. Common software process models will be introduced, along with developing an understanding of the importance of defining software requirements, developing software architectures and designs, and the various forms of testing that go into delivering reliable and resilient software systems.

metadata.recommended: Programming experience (in any language) is strongly recommended for graduate students
metadata.grading_basis: GRD - Regular Grades A, B, C, D, E

content: Techniques and algorithms for discovering patterns and knowledge from large datasets. Applications of data mining in software engineering contexts.
Software engineering principles applied to robotic systems. Programming and control of robots, sensor integration, and autonomous systems.
Attendance and participation in software engineering research colloquia. Students attend presentations by faculty, visiting scholars, and peers on current research topics.
Advanced study of operating system design and implementation including process management, memory management, file systems, and concurrent programming.
Probability theory and random processes with applications to engineering problems. Covers random variables, distributions, stochastic processes, and statistical inference.

metadata.course_title: Probability and Random Processes for Engineering Applications

content: Comprehensive coverage of cybersecurity concepts, theoretical foundations, and practical applications. Topics include cryptography, network security, and secure system design.
Web technologies and Internet of Things (IoT) systems. Development of web applications for IoT devices, protocols, and security considerations.
Machine learning algorithms and data analytics techniques applied to engineering problems. Covers supervised and unsupervised learning, neural networks, and data visualization.

metadata.course_title: Engineering Applications of Machine Learning and Data Analytics

content: Advanced computer architecture including processor design, memory hierarchies, parallel processing, and performance optimization.
System-level engineering of computer-based systems. Integration of hardware and software components, system design methodologies, and verification.
Design and optimization of embedded systems. Real-time constraints, resource optimization, and embedded software development.
Fundamental principles of artificial intelligence including search algorithms, knowledge representation, reasoning, planning, and learning.
Data science fundamentals for engineering applications. Statistical analysis, machine learning, data visualization, and big data technologies.

metadata.course_title: Fundamentals of Data Science for Engineers

content: Model-based systems engineering (MBSE) methodologies. Use of SysML and MBSE tools for system requirements, design, analysis, and verification.
Application of information technology and data science to biomedical and healthcare problems. Electronic health records, medical imaging, and clinical decision support.
PhD Software Engineering students must complete 16 units of non-dissertation coursework approved by faculty advisor and Director of Graduate Studies

metadata.phd_technical_electives: PhD Software Engineering students must complete 16 units of non-dissertation coursework approved by faculty advisor and Director of Graduate Studies
metadata.core_not_used: Any SFWE core courses not used to meet core coursework requirement can be used as technical electives
approved_sfwe_electives: SFWE 509 - Cloud Computing Principles and Practices (3)
SFWE 511 - Software for Industrial Control Systems (3)
approved_ece_electives: ECE 503 - Probability and Random Processes for Engineering Applications (3)
ECE 513 - Web Development and the IoT (3)
ECE 523 - Engineering Applications of Machine Learning and Data Analytics (3)
ECE 576A - Engineering of Computer Based Systems (3)
ECE 576B - Embedded System Design and Optimization (3)
approved_sie_electives: SIE 533 - Fundamentals of Data Science for Engineers (3)

content: BS Software Engineering is a 4-year (8 semester) program requiring 120-128 units including core SFWE courses, math, science, engineering, general education, technical electives, and capstone.
MS Software Engineering is a 30+ unit program (typically 2 years) with core courses, electives, and thesis or non-thesis options across diverse software and computer engineering domains.

metadata.notes: Students must complete 12 core courses and additional 3 courses. Flexibility to design course of study from diverse software and computer engineering domains including web/mobile applications, AI, cloud computing, embedded systems, cybersecurity, machine learning.

content: PhD Software Engineering is a 63+ unit doctoral program (typically 4-6 years) with core coursework, technical electives, minor requirement, qualifying and comprehensive exams, and dissertation research and defense.

core_required_courses: SFWE 513 (3 units) - Software Engineering Research Methods
SFWE 507 (3 units) - Foundations of Software Engineering
metadata.core_coursework_additional: 9 units from: SFWE 502 (DevSecOps), SFWE 503 (Project Management), SFWE 504 (Requirements Analysis), SFWE 505 (Architecture and Design), SFWE 506 (Distributed Computing)
metadata.technical_electives_units: 16 units non-dissertation coursework approved by faculty advisor and Director of Graduate Studies
metadata.colloquium_dissertation: 20 units total - SFWE 695A Colloquium (2 units) + SFWE 920 Dissertation Research (18 units)
metadata.minor_requirement: Required - 12 units total, can come from single discipline or split between two disciplines (6 units each)
metadata.substitution_policy: Students with BS in Software Engineering who have demonstrated core course competencies may substitute with SFWE 5xx level courses with advisor approval
metadata.doctoral_qualifying_exam: Assesses fundamental knowledge in specific SFWE domains, integrated understanding, and readiness for advanced graduate work
metadata.comprehensive_exam: Determines if student has sufficient background and expertise for dissertation research. Successful completion leads to formal admission to PhD candidacy
metadata.dissertation_requirements: Written document demonstrating all aspects of research including significance, literature review, methodologies, findings, discussion, limitations, impact, and future research potential
metadata.final_oral_defense: Public defense of dissertation with faculty committee appointed by Dean of Graduate College. Presentation open to public, followed by closed committee evaluation. Must be announced at least two weeks in advance

content: BS Software Engineering students must complete University of Arizona General Education requirements across Exploring Perspectives, Building Connections, and awareness areas.

metadata.general_education_requirements: BS Software Engineering students must complete University of Arizona General Education requirements

tier_2_exploring_perspectives.natural_scientist: Satisfied by foundational science courses (CHEM 151, PHYS 141)

metadata.building_connections: 9 units across multiple Building Connections courses
metadata.awareness_areas: Must include cultural, global, and historical awareness across courses

content: Students must achieve Advanced Standing in the College of Engineering before enrolling in 300-level and 400-level engineering courses.

metadata.advanced_standing_requirement: Students must achieve Advanced Standing in College of Engineering before enrolling in 300-level and 400-level engineering courses
metadata.consultation: Students should consult with academic advisor regarding Advanced Standing eligibility

content: BS Software Engineering students must complete technical electives (typically 9-12 units) to customize their education in approved areas such as web/mobile, embedded systems, cloud, cybersecurity, ML/AI, databases, and more.

metadata.technical_electives: BS Software Engineering students must complete technical electives to customize education
metadata.selection: Students should consult with faculty advisor for course approval and alignment with career goals

content: MS Software Engineering admission typically requires a minimum 3.0 GPA, a computing-related bachelors degree, prerequisite programming and CS knowledge, and English proficiency for international students. GRE is not required.

metadata.degree_background: Bachelor's degree from recognized university, preferably in computing-related field
prerequisite_knowledge: Programming experience in at least one language
Understanding of data structures and algorithms
metadata.english_proficiency: International students must demonstrate English proficiency (TOEFL, IELTS, PTE, or Duolingo)
metadata.additional_coursework: Students from non-computing backgrounds may be required to complete prerequisite courses

content: PhD Software Engineering admission typically requires a strong GPA (around 3.53.7), a computing-related degree, research experience, English proficiency, letters of recommendation, a statement of purpose, and identification of a potential faculty advisor. GRE is not required.

metadata.minimum_gpa: Typically 3.5 GPA for applicants with bachelor's degree, 3.7 GPA for applicants with master's degree
metadata.degree_background: Bachelor's or Master's degree in computing-related field
metadata.english_proficiency: International students must demonstrate English proficiency
metadata.statement_of_purpose: Required - should describe research interests and career goals
metadata.faculty_advisor: Students should identify potential faculty advisor with aligned research interests
